seg.seg: to be done [and] not to be done ... by the mean ... world
by hundreds ... they died because of clinging

p.note: Main text in Sanskrit, glosses in Sanskrit, TA and TB, plus a few entirely illegible ones.

Although the Sanskrit term is part of a compound p(a)rigrahakṛt· (see below), eṃ(tsā)luneyäṣ (abl.sg.; rather not eṃ(tsā)luneyaṣ, pace Peyrot apud 34; also the translation 'ergriffen habend' ['having seized, grasped'] given there is not exact) glosses only p(a)rigraha°. The precise function of the ablative of eṃ(tsā)luneyäṣ remains unclear: in any case, together with the following gloss yāmunt it does not form a coherent whole. yāmunt, then, glosses °kṛt· separately; there appears to be no syntactic relationship with the preceding gloss. yāmunt can be obl.sg.masc. or pl.fem.
eṃ(tsā)luneyäṣ glosses Skt. p(a)rigraha° 'possession; taking'. yāmunt glosses Skt. °kṛt· 'having done'.

It is remarkable that all Tocharian glosses to this fragment are in TA, except for śaiṣṣe (however, there are also some glosses in Sanskrit and a couple that are so fragmentary that not even the language can be established (see 34-5), which are not discussed here). There seems to be no palaeographical difference between the TA glosses and this gloss in TB. It is unclear why only this word should be glossed in TB: might it be because TB śaiṣṣe is only two syllables, twice as short as the TA equivalent ārkiśoṣi?

(ya)l mā yal glosses Skt. k(ār)yākārya° 'to be done and not to be done'. 279 reads only the second half of the gloss: mā yal. Nevertheless, a trace of the first yal can be seen rather clearly, even though the first akṣara is hardly visible. The second, kärpisyo, glosses Skt. anāryair (instr. pl.) 'by the mean'. The third item, TB śaiṣṣe, glosses Skt. jagat 'world'.
käntantuyo is an instr.pl. As pointed out by Dieter Maue (p.c.; see also 34), the second gloss träṅkluneyo wlär must be an explanation of the Sanskrit text, not a translation.
käntantuyo glosses Skt. śataśau (for śataśo) 'a hundred times'. träṅkluneyo wlär glosses Skt. trigartā hatāḥ 'the Trigarta women were killed'.

ārskoṃ must stand for ārts koṃ. ānāptune clearly contains the abstract suffix -une, but is further unclear. Conceivable is a connection with the adverb āptā 'before', i.e. a negated 'what was not before'. Any relationship with āpti 'right' does not seem likely; also an alternative reading āwāptune is probably not to be preferred.
ārskoṃ glosses Skt. – – [ra]ha, which is probably to be restored as (aha)raha for aharahaṃ or aharahar (or aharahaḥ) 'day by day' (34). ānāptune glosses Skt. navaśamaṃ '(with) new tranquility (?)'.
